Entities.Name: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
Entities.Definition: A disease that occurs when the blood vessels that supply the heart with oxygen and nutrients become narrowed or blocked.

Sample Data.Annotated Sentence: In addition, CAD, diabetes, hypertension, CHF

Entities.Name: Diabetes
Entities.Definition: A chronic disease characterized by high blood sugar levels due to the body's inability to produce or properly use insulin.

Sample Data.Annotated Sentence: PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Remarkable for seizure, type II diabetes mellitus

Entities.Name: Hypertension
Entities.Definition: A condition where the blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated.

Sample Data.Annotated Sentence: Medications include for hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia

Entities.Name: Hyperlipidemia
Entities.Definition: A condition where there are high levels of lipids (fats) in the blood.

Sample Data.Annotated Sentence: PMH: S/p mechanical aortic valve replacement, CHF, HTN, hyperlipidemia

Entities.Name: Obesity
Entities.Definition: A medical condition involving excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.

Entities.Name: Smoking Status
Entities.Definition: An individual's history of tobacco use, categorized as current, past, ever, never, or unknown.

Sample Data.Annotated Sentence: Currently smoking a pack per day

Entities.Name: Family History of CAD
Entities.Definition: Indicates whether the patient has first-degree relatives diagnosed with CAD.

Entities.Name: Medication
Entities.Definition: Drugs prescribed for treatment, categorized into Type 1 (drug category) and Type 2 (drugs belonging to multiple categories).

Dataset.Name: i2b2/UTHealth 2014 Challenge Dataset
Dataset.Details: A dataset comprising 514 annotated clinical notes used for extracting heart disease risk factors. The data includes mentions of CAD, hypertension, diabetes, obesity, hyperlipidemia, smoking status, family history of CAD, and medications.

Annotation Guidelines.Description: Guidelines for annotating heart disease risk factors in clinical notes, including the detection of disease mentions, symptoms, and associated indicators.
